publicationStmt.p: This material to follow is a three-part series to compare the modern transcription, initial transcription from Sir Edward Maunde Thompson at the British Library, and a look at rhetorial shifts in spelling and punctuation. This conglomerate of work is a way to take the past research that has been staticly transcribed of for several years and concoct a method of direct comparison.Simply put, this work scrutinizes the four leaves of the Sir Thomas More manuscript that are thought to be written by Hand D (suspected writing of William Shakespeare). This is one of the most discussed works in the early modern paleographic field so having the opportunity to engage in that ongoing conversation will prove fruitful for the early modern dramatic community. It is by placing this material in conversation with one another that we gain a deeper understanding for the characters within the scripted characters left behind.

sourceDesc.p:
The manuscript is currrently housed at the British Library. The manuscript for the Sir Thomas More play is perhaps the most universal methodlogy we have to attain an understanding of paleography from Shakespeare given the limited content we have access to in the signatures that remain. The physical document is in very good condition but more importantly it is a clean set of four pages simultaneous noting handwriting in succession.This manuscript holds a higher topic of debate than any other pages throughout the dramatic manuscript and interestingly enough many scholars are more interested in who wrote it rather than what the content tells us dramatically. In a sense, this set of manuscript paged is the sole dramatic piece by Shakespeare that prioritizes authorship to such a degree that the story Shakespeare is telling becomes secondary. Between footnotes and internal analysis this digitized model will elucidate on what this means and what may be gleaned from unpacking this form as a historian, paleographer, and practitioner.
Sir Thomas More manuscript collection
William Shakespeare
Manuscript Collection housed at the British Library
1516

div.p: This manuscript is perhaps one of the most talked about yet likewise most misunderstood of documents in the early modern dramatic canon. Historically, this has become know as the manuscript with many hands and the Hand D persona is thought to belong to that of playwright William Shakespeare. Comparing this materiality to that of the handwriting on legal documents shows this Hand D to truly be Shakespeare. This text is signifigant because it is the only surviving consecutive pages and fully fleshed content we have surviving in Shakespeare's hand. Other than this material we only have a handful of signatures that remain. This work aligns this material in a unique historical context as it speaks to the process of material culture but also offers a modernization to make it accessible for those who would not find secretary hand attainable to decipher. This moment has the past speak in tandem with the present to better understand both the style of the time as well as the historical context. This is the only direct moment in Shakespeare's hand we have dramatically, and for a playwright so well known to have limited access to this handwritten piece neglects a major archival wonderment that this work will unpack and present.

In this edition, I am trying to create a direct editorial comparison of the current transcriptions and modernize the spelling to make it more attainableand approachable to the reader. Since there is the ability to click between 3 separate instances, readers can see paleographic notes as well as understandthe articulation of the meaning within a modern context. This will widen the access of the information for people who do not understand paleography to better understand what is happening in the dramatic text to glean a better sense of what the text may be able to offer them about the life of historical figure Sir Thomas More but also drama in the early modern period as a whole. What readers get out of this edition is access and deeper understanding. You do not need to be an archivist or paleographer to appreciate this text with this particular edition. In this way, this work enlightens a brand new understanding of a text that they otherwise would not be able to fully understand. The meaning of the scene comes from the beauty of the words and without comprehension, the manuscript will not tell that story.

The process for editing this took a lot of time to concoct exactly what presentation would most suit my intended audience to widen the sphere of accessibility. The main editorial decisions came from a desire to make the unreadible readable to both the common eye and the high level paleographer. For this reason, my work is divided into three separate segments. The Maunde transcription, my transcription to compare, and a modernized spelling and puncutuation version. These can be clicked back and forth to see the variability and comprehend the history and changing of the text. Each transcription has a focus, the Maunde is to digitize the undigitized as a point of comparison and the transcription of my own work is to speak to the paleographers in the audience. The modern rendition should be as accessible as possible to everyone else. I tried to make that section speak to a sense of continuity, clarity, and the modern reader. I did not change wording or context but I did edit spelling for clarity. With these spelling situations, the text becomes so clear that any reader can perceive what is occurring in the scene. Most importantly, this project is designed in such a way that asks about the universality of the material at hand to best realize and understand context, situation, materiality, history, and language of a very intriguing manuscript.

div.head: Performance Edition Edited by: Amanda Marie Rogus

sp.p: Peace, hear me! He that will not see a red hearing at a hairy goat butter at eleven pence a pound meal at nine shillings a Bushell and Beef at flower nobles a stone list to me.
It will Come to the pass if strangers be suffered mark him.
Our Country is a great eating Country, ergo they eat more in our Country then they do in their own.
By half penny lost a day tray weight.
They bring in straying roots, which is merely to the undoing of poor prentises, for what's a watery or sorry snipp to a good heart.
Trash trash; they breed sore eyes and this is enough to infect the City with the palsey.

Nay, it infected it with the palsey, for these bastards of dung as you know they grow in Dung have infected us, and it it our infection will make the City shake patiently Comes through the eating snips.
True and pumkins together!
What say you to the mercy of the king do you refuse it.
You would have us upon think would you no marry do we not, we accept of the kings mercy but wee show no mercy upon the strangers.
You are the simplest things that ever stood in such a question.
How say you now prince princesses simple down with him all princesses simple princesses simple?
Hold in the kings name! Hold!
Friends, masters, Countrymen!
Peace! How peace! I should Charge you! Keep the peace!
My masters Countrymen!
The noble Earl of Shrewsbury, lets hear him!
We'll heare the Earl of Surrey!
The Earl of Shrewsbury!
We'll hear both!
Both! Both! Both! Both!
Peace, I say! Peace, are you men of Wisdom? Are? Or what are you?
But what you have them but not men of Wisdom?
We'll not hear my Lord of Surrey! No! No! No! No! No! Shrewsbury, sir...
Whiles the are our the bank of their obedience, thus will they bear down all things.
Sheriff More speaks, shall we hear sheriff moor speak?
Let's hear him. He keeps a plentiful chivalry, and a made my Brother Arthur watch his Servant Saves yeoman let's hear Sheriff More.
Sheriff More! More, More Sheriff More!
Even by the rule you have among your salutes command still audience!
Surrey! Surrey!
More! More!
Peace, peace! Silence! Peace.
You that have voice and Credit wth the my Command! Command them to a silence!
A plague on them they will not hold their peace the duel Cannot rule them!
Then what a rough and riotous charge have you to Lead those that the duel Cannot rule good masters hear me speak.
I both must will we moor thou art a good housekeeper and I thank thy good worship for my Brother Arthur watches.
Peace! Peace!

Look what you do offend you Cry upon that is the peace, not of you here present had there such fellows, lived when you were babes that could have topped the peace as now you would the peace wherein you have till now grown up had been taken from you, and the bloody times could not have brought you to the current state of men alas poor things what is yt you have got although we grant you get the thing you seek!
Marry, the removing of the strangers which cannot choose, but much help the advantage of the poor handy crafts of the City!

Grant them removed and grant that this your I noise hath Chid down all the might of England, imagine that you see the wretched strangers their babies all their backs, and their poor luggage plodding tooth ports and costs for transportation and that you sit as kings in your desires authority quite silenced by your brawl and you in ruff of your our opinions clothed what had you got, I'll tell you, you had taught how insolence and strong hand should prevail how order should be quelld, and by this pattern not on of you should live an aged man for other ruffians as their fancies wrought with self same hand self reasons and self right would shared on you and men like ravenous fishes would feed on on another.
Before God! That's as true as the gospel!
Lincoln! Nay, this a sound fellow I tell you lets mark him!

Let me set up before your thoughts good friends on supposition which if you will mark. You shall see how horrible a shape your innovation bares, first it is a sin, which if it the apostle did fore warne us of urging obedience to authority and it were no error if I told you all you were in arms against God.

div.div:
++++++++++++++++++
Harley MS 7368, folio 9 recto
all
Marry, God forbid that!
moor
Nay, certainly you are for to the king God hath his office lent of dread of justice, power and Command hath bid him rule, and willed you to obey and to add ampler might if to this. He God hath not let only lent the king his figure his throne his sword, but given him his own name calls him a God on earth, what do you then rising against him that God himself installs but rise against God, what do you to your souls in doing this on desperate are as you are. Wash your foul minds with tears and those same hands that you like rebels lift against the peace, lift up for peace, and your unvenerate knees that make them your feet to kneel to be forgiven is safer wisdom that ever you can make whose discipline I'd riot; why even your war is early in in to your obedience! Cannot proeed but by obedience! TELL ME BUT THIS, what rebel captain as mutiny or incident, by his name can still the root who will obey the a traitor of how can well that proclamation sound when there is no addiction but a rebel? To qualify a rebel, you'll be put down strangers kill them cut their throats possess their houses and lead the mighty of law and lion to slip him like a hound; saying alas alas say now the king as he is clement, if the offendor mourn should so much come to short of your great trespass as but to banish you, whether would you go. What Country by the nature of your error should give you harbor go you to France or Flanders to any Larman Province, to Spain or Portegal, nay anywhere why youthat not adheres to England. Why you must needs be strangers. would you be pleased to find a nation of such barberous temper that breaking out in hidious violence. Would not afford you, an abode on earth when it their detested knives against your throats spurn you like dogs, and like as if that God owed not nor made not you, nor that the elements wer not all appropriate to their your Comforts. But Chartered unto them, what would you thick to be thus used, this is the strangers case.
all
And this your mountanous inhumanity faith a says true! Let us do as we may be done by!
[all] all
LINCO LINCOLN
We'll be ruled by you master moor if you'll stand our friend to procure our pardon.
moor
Submit you to these noble gentleman entreat their mediation to the king give up your self to form obey the majistrate and there's no doubt, but mercy may be found. if you so seek it.

note.p: Due to the context and position of this line on the page, scholars often feel that these three pages may actually be an insert or revision forum from the initial comments by playwright Anthony Munday

bibl.title: The Booke of Sir Thomas More and Its Problems

note.p: Lines such as this make scholars question the goal of constructing this dramatic work. Clearly, this contextually frames it as a non biographic work, but the drama has its own unique sense of stichomythia and overlapping that makes it appear as more than a story to the audience observing.

bibl.title: Shakespeare's Hand in the Play of Sir Thomas More

note.p: This edit comes from W.W.Greg's notes from the edition published by the Malone Society unpacking the details of what is happening in the play contextually. Edward Maunde Thompson listened to Greg in this particular instance, but it is clear that his transcription is seeking a different audience than the explantory venture in the facsimile made in 1844.

Brilliant stage actor Sir Ian McKellen discusses the rhythm of this line and how it speaks to a greater sense of Shakespearean rhetoric when compared to his other dramas showing yet more proof now in the performative realm that this is indeed a text of the great William Shakespeare.

Framing the note to the performer in this way may appear to be a bit direct from a playwright to the modern eye but in early modern England there were no directors so notes this direct were actually quite common to see in manuscripts.

bibl.title: The Elizabethan Theatre and the Book of Sir Thomas More

note.p: The protagonist of the play. He is the sheriff who also serves as a high level member of the local church.
A town official who is rallying to gain higher power within the govering organization.
The town mayor's assistant who always enters before him to ensure saftey and clarity of thought.
The representative from Shrewsberry who often argues with Thomas More about his ideas.
The representative from Surrey who almost always agrees with the mayor.
The deputy director of finances for the town center business district.
The deputy who follows More around like a puppy.
The leader of the town who often causes concern for those in the church.
Minor characters in the town square that often serve as a crowd to rally.
Minor character who delivers messages to and from the Mayor's office.

listBibl.bibl: Bald, R.C.. The Booke of Sir Thomas More and Its Problems. 1st Edition, Cambridge University Press, 1949, Cambridge.
McKellen, Ian. Sir Thomas More. 1st Edition, Ian McKellen Stage, 2012, Cambridge.
McMilin, Scott. The Elizabethan Theatre and the Book of Sir Thomas More. 2nd Edition, Cornell University Press, 1987, New York.
Pollard, Alfred. Shakespeare's Hand in the Play of Sir Thomas More. 2nd Edition, Cambridge University Press, 1923, Cambridge.
Thompson, Edward Maunde. Shakespeare's Handwriting: A Study. 1st Edition, Oxford University Press, 1916, Oxford.
